The yellow arrow is pointing towards the inner limiting membrane (ILM), a hyper-reflective line at the border of the inner retina and the pre-retinal space. There is a dense hyper-reflective area under the ILM that corresponds to the hemorrhage seen in the fundus photograph.

questions.title: Question 1
questions.text: The fundus photograph demonstrates a macular hemorrhage in the left eye. What layer of the retina is the hemorrhage situated in?

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
![](/content/media/retina-11-3.webp)

The red arrow is pointing to an arrow of hypo-reflectivity underneath the hemorrhage. What does this represent?

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-11-3.webp)

Certain ocular components can absorb light, which may induce a shadowing effect. In this case, the superficial macular hemorrhage has absorbed the light leading to an area of hypo-reflectivity due to the shadowing effect. This hides the intra-retinal and outer-retinal structures from view.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Of the following choices, which can cause sub-ILM hemorrhages?

answers.explanation:
Sub-ILM hemorrhages have been described in a variety of clinical settings including all the choices listed above. In our case, the hemorrhage was thought to be secondary to her thrombocytopenia. Other causes include:

1. Valsalva retinopathy
2. Ocular trauma
3. Terson's syndrome
4. Retinal macroaneurysm

title: Case 11
description: 27F presenting with 1-week history of decreased vision OS
patientPresentation:
A 27-year-old female presented to the ophthalmology clinic with a 1-week history of decreased vision in the left eye. She had a history of renal transplantation and was on immunosuppressive medications. Her most recent blood work demonstrated anemia and thrombocytopenia. She denied history of trauma. On examination, vision was 20/20 OD and 20/150 OS. Pupils were equal and reactive to light. Fundus photograph and OCT macula are shown below:
